input2:
The patient with a history of aortic stenosis s/p porcine valve replacement.  
She stated that this fatigue has been increasing over the past two weeks.  In the past few days, she says that she has become increasingly short of breath. According to the chart, she experienced chest pain during her visit to her primary care physician (PCP). However, when asked about it today, she mentioned that the pain was related to her cough. She described the pain as a substernal soreness and noted that she has recently started coughing up blood-tinged sputum. (She typically has a productive cough due to her asthma.) Earlier today, she was sent to the emergency department after her oxygen saturation levels dropped at her PCP's office. She denied experiencing syncope, lightheadedness, or palpitations. At baseline, she has two-pillow orthopnea but no history of paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea (PND). Additionally, she reports recent nausea but denies any abdominal pain, vomiting, or diarrhea.

GENERAL- WDWN lying in bed in NAD. Oriented x3. Mood, affect appropriate.  
HEENT- NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI NECK- Supple with JVP of 10 cm.  
CARDIAC- PMI located in intercostal space, midclavicular line. RR, normal S1, S2 with distinct systolic murmur audible at all points anteriorly.  
LUNGS- Midline scar present. Resp were unlabored, no accessory muscle use. Breath sounds dulled at bases; crackles bilaterally midway up lungs.  
ABDOMEN- Soft, NTND. No HSM or tenderness.   
EXTREMITIES- No c/c/e.  
SKIN- L shin warm and slightly red; R shin discolored with bruise

Studies:
- CXR: "New mild-to-moderate interstitial abnormality, most suggestive of congestive heart failure."

- UNITLAT LOW EXT VEINS: "No evidence of deep vein thrombosis."

- ECG 11:21:06 AM "Sinus arrhythmia. Left atrial abnormality. Possible prior anteroseptal myocardial infarction. 
Borderline left ventricular hypertrophy with associated ST segment changes. Compared to the previous tracing of the ventricular rate is faster and atrial ectopy is no longer appreciated"

- TTE: "The left atrium is mildly dilated. No atrial septal defect is seen by 2D or color Doppler. The estimated right atrial pressure is 120 mmHg. There is moderate symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy. The left ventricular cavity size is normal. Regional left ventricular wall motion is normal. Overall left ventricular systolic function is normal (LVEF>55%). Tissue Doppler imaging suggests an increased left ventricular filling pressure (PCWP>18mmHg). There is a mild resting left ventricular outflow tract obstruction. Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The diameters of aorta at the sinus, ascending and arch levels are normal. A bioprosthetic aortic valve prosthesis is present. The prosthetic aortic valve leaflets appear normal The transaortic gradient is higher than expected for this type of prosthesis. Trace aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation is seen. [Due to acoustic shadowing, the severity of mitral regurgitation may be significantly UNDERestimated.] Moderate [2+] tricuspid regurgitation is seen. The estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure is normal. There is no pericardial effusion.
